title: Empty Pill Bottles Piling Up? Here Are 15 Great Ways to Reuse Them
author: Jesslyn Shields
description: Wondering what to do with those plastic pill bottles your prescriptions come in? Here are 15 great ways to reuse them and keep them out of the landfill.
cleaned_text: Over [64 percent](https://www.singlecare.com/blog/news/prescription-drug-statistics/) of Americans take one or more prescription drugs. From antibiotics to antidepressants, 4.7 billion prescriptions were dispensed in 2022. That's a lot of heavy-duty plastic to deal with! Pill containers are usually made of number five [plastic](https://science.howstuffworks.com/environmental/green-tech/sustainable/question217.htm) (polypropylene, or PP), which is what yogurt containers and many reusable food-safe containers are made of. You can tell if you're dealing with a number five recyclable plastic by looking at the bottom of the container for the chasing arrows with the number 5 in the middle. These common plastics are great because they're lightweight, strong, can deal with a wide range of temperatures, and they keep whatever's inside dry. Advertisement These plastics also take years to break down in the environment, and as they age, they release toxic chemicals and [methane](https://www.unep.org/news-and-stories/story/double-trouble-plastics-found-emit-potent-greenhouse-gases), a dangerous greenhouse gas into the environment. So, if you're one of the millions of people who have empty pill bottles lying around your house, you might be wondering what to do with them. Of course, in some cases, you can recycle them — some cities have [curbside recycling programs](https://recyclenation.com/find/?family_id=9&materials=6) that accept number five plastics.
